/lit/ is for the discussion of literature, specifically books (fiction & non-fiction), short stories, poetry, creative writing, etc. If you want to discuss history, religion, or the humanities, go to /his/. If you want to discuss politics, go to /pol/. Philosophical discussion can go on either /lit/ or /his/, but those discussions of philosophy that take place on /lit/ should be based around specific philosophical works to which posters can refer.

Check the wiki, the catalog, and the archive before asking for advice or recommendations, and please refrain from starting new threads for questions that can be answered by a search engine.

/lit/ is a slow board! Please take the time to read what others have written, and try to make thoughtful, well-written posts of your own. Bump replies are not necessary.

I've read LotR several times, although it has been a decade since I last touched it.
I actually enjoyed Atlas Shrugged for the most part, even if the sections where she tries to explain metaphysics manage to be both dull and juvenile. I've heard that the Fountainhead is better (and shorter) but I somehow I feel I learnt all there is to learn about Rand from AS.
The part where Gately breaks his leg kicking the Québécois was a surprisingly enthralling action sequence, and I wasn't expecting any action so deep into the novel.
I've only read Poetics, so I won't comment on the rest. A random titbit I remember offhand is his example of metaphor: In the Iliad it is said that 'all were asleep', during the book in which Odysseus does his sneak mission. Obviously not all were asleep, since Odysseus & friends, as well as some guards if I remember rightly, are awake. Instead it's used as a metaphor to mean that /almost/ all were asleep. That's not really the way metaphors get talked about these days.

>>21501645
It's not about having things. Being healthy and 'happy' means being a body fully engaged in the world, exerting your capacity to affect and being affected. For some reason it's only the Stoic pseudo-wisemen who insist that everyone is obsessed with obtaining possessions and status. Everyone else intuitively knows that what they want out of a well-lived, joyful existence is something much more active than obtaining desired objects. You can have a painful, agonizing relationship and still have it be meaningful and life-changing. That sadness is not depression. Depression means that your capacities are dimmed, you're a shade, you're removed from the world. There's no solution to it other than finding small, creative ways back into the world and patiently regaining your health. Of course it's transient and painful, but it's better than the nullity of this life-hating Stoic attitude that claims 'it's all meaningless vanity' -- that's the truest and most awful kind of depression, the permanent entombment in the Wise Man's Tower, sealing yourself away from the world.

The battlefield is not limited to war in the strictly geopolitical sense. The pic here >>21501665 is of Mishima who "died in glorious battle."
The words of Seneca:
>Take, for example, Scipio, the father-in-law of Gnaeus Pompeius: he was driven back upon the African coast by a head-wind and saw his ship in the power of the enemy. He therefore pierced his body with a sword; and when they asked where the commander was, he replied: “All is well with the commander.”
>These words brought him up to the level of his ancestors and suffered not the glory which fate gave to the Scipios in Africa to lose its continuity. It was a great deed to conquer Carthage, but a greater deed to conquer death. “All is well with the commander!” Ought a general to die otherwise, especially one of Cato’s generals?
Though he did not die at arms in a typical fashion, he still died in glorious battle- as did Cato, who died "fighting" in glorious battle against what he considered tyranny.
>Drawing the sword, – which he had kept unstained from all bloodshed against the final day, – he cried: “Fortune, you have accomplished nothing by resisting all my endeavours. I have fought, till now, for my country’s freedom, and not for my own, I did not strive so doggedly to be free, but only to live among the free. Now, since the affairs of mankind are beyond hope, let Cato be withdrawn to safety.”
It is not necessary to be felled by your enemy directly, or even to have a corporeal enemy at all. To fight for what is good, even if one is fated to lose as Cato, is glorious battle.

>Finally, brethren, whatever is true, whatever is honorable, whatever is right, whatever is pure, whatever is lovely, whatever is of good repute, if there is any excellence and if anything worthy of praise, dwell on these things. ~ Phillipians 4:8

>A thing of beauty is a joy for ever:
Its loveliness increases; it will never
Pass into nothingness; but still will keep
A bower quiet for us, and a sleep
Full of sweet dreams, and health, and quiet breathing.
Therefore, on every morrow, are we wreathing
A flowery band to bind us to the earth,
Spite of despondence, of the inhuman dearth
Of noble natures, of the gloomy days,
Of all the unhealthy and o'er-darkened ways
Made for our searching: yes, in spite of all,
Some shape of beauty moves away the pall
From our dark spirits. Such the sun, the moon,
Trees old and young, sprouting a shady boon
For simple sheep; and such are daffodils
With the green world they live in; and clear rills
That for themselves a cooling covert make
'Gainst the hot season; the mid forest brake,
Rich with a sprinkling of fair musk-rose blooms:
And such too is the grandeur of the dooms
We have imagined for the mighty dead;
All lovely tales that we have heard or read:
An endless fountain of immortal drink,
Pouring unto us from the heaven's brink.

Nor do we merely feel these essences
For one short hour; no, even as the trees
That whisper round a temple become soon
Dear as the temple's self, so does the moon,
The passion poesy, glories infinite,
Haunt us till they become a cheering light
Unto our souls, and bound to us so fast,
That, whether there be shine, or gloom o'ercast;
They always must be with us, or we die.

>>21501968
>Expand on this please.
Just a few times, I've witnessed in person someone accomplishing such a pure and total expression of their will without compromise or flaw that it rivalled any depiction of that kind of virtue in art. When I try to envision death I imagine intensively a real-world location I presently am not, such as my city's city centre or the lobby downstairs, and then imagine extending that feeling of non-being outwards to cover everywhere, all coordinates in the plane of existence. And when I witnessed these things it was as if the force of will present was so total I to all intents and purposes did not exist, in this same sense, and had total catharsis from any suffering or pain or simply the tightly-knotted sensation of being that I might have been experiencing. Not to say simply that I was getting something out of this experience, but that this absence was one way of verifying that some stimuli had provoked something in me. It felt like the consummation of the world, like being sucked through the self-intersection of the universe's Klein bottle and seeing the entire thing as a perfect and limitless circle drawn freehand. What I do think is impossible for a human being is holding onto it for more than an instant, but I think partly through intent and partly through luck and accident it is quite possible to transit through the path of perfection as a matter of course. It's this that I want to make myself a part of both out of purer libido and also so that I don't feel so inadequate in the face of it.

These moments all occurred before adulthood though, and like for many people the world and its prospects have been growing dimmer the past decade. I'm sure it won't be that way forever, but within the timescale of the rest of my lifetime, I'm not so optimistic. On top of that, I feel like I am permanently on the outside of this phenomenon and will only ever be a voyeur to it, for various reasons. I'm poor, I'm physically ugly, I'm disabled (brain damage from a hypoxic birth injury + palsy from the same + genetic connective tissue disorder, also causing me physical pain) which has stopped me from developing physical and mental skills through practice like most people, I'm not lucky enough to have been born with any inherent talents, I'm not an evil person or anything but also not much fun to be around IRL socially, and so on. Having these sorts of problems is rough enough on its own (I've only glimpsed the kind of agony the human body is capable of experiencing, and I hope even a natural death doesn't feel like that for half a second more) but having been granted a taste of what's possible and then not being able to do anything with it feels like an utterly schematic kind of cruelty that I can't even do anything with artistically. It's just plain dissatisfaction and, as I said before, nothing to write home about.

>>21502483
>a narrative implies motion

Most narratives start and end in the same place. The hero leaves the village, fights the demon, returns home with his new experience and sees his old home in a new way. Narrative is not about going from A to B, or moving from here to there, it's about looking at the same shit you've been looking at your whole life with new eyes/perspective. You lack perspective. If you had perspective and distance from your own bullshit for a moment you would see this, and you would see how your fear of comparison and paralysis of 'the trodden path' is pure nonsense (there is no path until you walk on it yourself. You have no idea what there is or isn't until you've done it. When you walk the path you are the path. And you are unique, whether you believe it or not.).

What you need to do is let go of what you think you know, because it clearly is doing you no good and you are completely blind to yourself and other ways of seeing. Right now you are firmly at home on your journey, looking out at a horizon that you want to explore, but you refuse to and bullshit yourself about what might be there for you. The first comment had it immediately correct >>21501539 but you probably overlooked that as simplistic advice in the same way you dismiss that well trodden path you have never dared to step foot on.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21505653
>Now this I don't get, I'd consider personal experience to be the most vital ingredient in the palette of any artist in any medium
As someone who has little personal experience, you believe that personal experience is essential to art? Are you intentionally trying to find reasons not to write?
>how can you write anything truthful if...
Truth keeps coming up again and again and again. Maybe this is where your philosophy is breaking down. Ultimate, human-independent truth already exists. It's everywhere you look, in your sensory data; everywhere. If you want to somehow capture it, maybe take up physics or photography. Literature doesn't deal with strict, ultimate truths. Those are stark, and without human experience to tinge them, boring.

I used to get caught up in mind games like this as well. My solution, whenever I find myself falling into them, is to ask myself a simple question:
>do I want to write or do I want to quit?
If I want to write, there is only one action that will fulfill this desire: writing. All of these meta-discussions and worries about whether or not you're good enough, sufficiently well-read, talented, boring, experienced, whatever—they distract you from that one simple question. Do you want to write, or don't you?

For me, the answer is always yes. Yes, I do want to write. So I say, "fuck the rest," open up my laptop, and write. I'm going to do that right now, and I invite you to join me.

Or not; whatever.

You are presumably confused about the fact that 'eros' is indeed used poetically to describe strong physical desire including hunger. But in conventional Greek usage, in 99% of cases, it means romantic love. Which is why Eros (in Rome, Cupid) is the god of love, and not of bread. Which is why the theme of the Symposium, where the speakers are asked to praise the god Eros, is human relationships and not food. If you deny this then discussion in ancient Greece about "eros" between men and women becomes nonsense. Have you read Lysis? The theme of that dialogue is an attempt philosophically to define 'philia' or friendship or non-sexual love. It is contrasted against 'eros'. The friendship between the boys Lysis and Menexenus is contrasted with the crush Hippothales has on Lysis.

>I can vizualize it perfectly but I can't draw it.
With all due respect, I'm skeptical of people who say things like this. I've spent enough time arguing about media on the internet to know that there's no lack of idea-guys. Everyone thinks that they could write a novel, direct a movie, or design a video game if only they had the technical skill or resources. That doesn't mean they can actually do it. I think a lot of people who actually do art know that, once you try putting your ideas into practice, you realise that you're not actually as creative as you thought you were. Having an idea in your head is not the same thing as being able to actualize it.

This is, ultimately, my problem with AI art - the idea that there are thousands of people who have great ideas but are somehow unable to learn the technical side of things. The fact that art takes effort to make is a good thing because it filters out the people who aren't committed enough. If you're so confident in your own vision then you should be able to go through the effort of learning how to actualise it. If AI art ever becomes anything more than a novelty, I think all it's going to achieve is making art oversaturated and disposable. There will be so much generic stuff being made that it will make the laziest seasonal anime look like Kurosawa. I'm not a luddite. I have no problem with AI being used to automate menial jobs or to solve problems that the human brain isn't well suited for, but I just don't see any point to using to create art.

Computers are tools for the reproduction of capital, and capital will continue to summon new machines and programs lest it be pushed back to the dark ages of people and paper. To become intolerant, even hateful, of computers is to strike at the center of the modern desire-production that you describe - whether any of this is sustainable long-term I am hesitant to predict. But I'm already speaking like a utopian.

>>21502117
>You can ask people if they think it looks good or not.
This is not testability. One game of chess, for any individual player, has one of three exclusive outcomes: win, loss, draw. A win is always preferable to a draw, which is always preferable to a loss. There are rules which clearly delineate all three scenarios, with which there is precisely zero ambiguity. Writing cannot be a win, a loss, or a draw. There is no objective framework from which you can evaluate these things. The closest you can get is commercial success. The problem is that commercially successful writing often isn't very good. How do you deterministically—in the vein of chess' strict causality—reconcile Ulysses with 50 Shades?

I think AI is good at visual art because it is less abstract. A shape can be quantified and tied to reality. There are spheres and squares and triangles in the material world which provide the backdrop for a more deterministic learning model. A smiley face is an open half circle and two small closed dots inside a larger circle. A hat is a closed half-circle with a line protruding its brim. From this "understanding," AI can learn (by methods nobody genuinely understands, even its programmers) the ways in which individual human artists iterate on the idea of a smiley face. One artist may draw a smiley face with a thicker line, another may offset the mouth or make it crooked. There are complex patterns in visual art which can be collated given a wide enough dataset, and it all ties back to quantifiable collections and combinations of basic shapes.

Writing is much more abstract. What makes GOOD writing, even moreso. Writing deals not just with visual sights but smells, sounds, concepts, meaning; and it deals with these things without ever actually "instantiating" any one of them. It is purely descriptive and allusive by nature.

All of this is something with which AI still struggles... and we haven't even gotten into the manipulation and modulation of the medium itself, which is the bread and butter of the very best human literature.

>>21503025
There's a couple of related purposes to the math/science part of the program. Otoh, a bunch of these readings go hand in hand with laboratory practicums (dissecting a heart reading Harvey, chemistry experiments with Lavoisier, weight and balance experiments with Archimedes and Pascal, etc), where part of the point is to learn how science developed by seeing for ourselves whether the experiments bear out the observations and conclusions of various thinkers. But in addition, since here is some broad cultural agreement on the notion of modernity being a kind of crisis, reading older workks of math and science offer an opportunity to grapple with their development and increasingly important role in culture and politics. For example, Vieta is read in sequence with some equations by Diophantus and followed up with Descartes' Geometrie to see how arithmetic comes to treat geometrical quantities and magnitudes. This is really another way of being able to see concretely what we gain and lose by formulating algebra. Similarly, we go through Ptolemy, Copernicus, Galileo, and Kepler to investigate what was involved in trying to establish the order of the solar system.

IMHO Cherryh's best stuff is Chanur (space merchant lionesses!), Cyteen (if you replace the smartest person in the universe with a clone raised from infancy, can you truly control them?) And Downbelow Station (political intrigues threaten a giant space station hovering above a resource-rich planet. Humans and gentle apelike aliens are both in grave danger). The latter haunted my sleep for several days, the suspense of the station just a few steel plates removed from open space really got at me.

>>21502873
Fuck yes to Bujold. I’ve reread her books so many times. Vorkosigan’s my favorite, but Penric & Desdemona is fun as heck, and World of the Five Gods is pretty singular. (Anon’s Chalion.)
I also love Joan D. Vinge. The Snow Queen, The Summer Queen and World’s End have been a few of my favorite books since i was a kid, and her Cat books grew on me over the years.
Cherryh is definitely top of the line. I agree 100% with Cyteen, Regenesis (Cy’s sequel,) and Downbelow Station.
James Tiptree Jr’s written some unforgettable short stories that are pretty indescribable. Tepper’s Grass makes you shiver, Elizabeth Moon’s Remnant Population is probably the single most entertaining story I’ve read, on a personal tongue-in-cheek level. I loved Nancy Kress’s Sleepless series, Patricia Wrede, Madeline L’Engle, Mercedes Lackey, Diane Duane, Lynn Flewelling, Robin Hobb and Dianna Wynne Jones in the kids’ books vein are old classics, though that’s moving towards fantasy. There are a bunch more hidden giants, too. Shelley for example, since we don’t really think of her books as science fiction, nowadays.
In trying recent titles, Planetfall and Atlas Alone by Newman were pretty interesting for a new author’s yield— they felt like kid slush at first, but the psychological warping in the minds of the characters felt very vivid and provoked interesting and colorful reflections on their surroundings that I ended up really warming to. I loved the house of reclaimed waste. That idea will stick with me for a long time.

The problem with death in modern fiction is that it is generally used as a crutch, an easy way to score drama points with cheap emotional tricks or to write yourself out of a sticky situation because you forgot what you wanted to do with a character. In other words, it's the first and last resort of bad writers who don't know how to write endings, so they just kill the person before their story is finished and shift focus to a new character that they can kill before their story is finished and shift focus to a new character...ad infinitum to avoid ever having to write the most important part of a story: the conclusion.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21503759
Joseph W. Campbell, Jr. is famous for writing Who Goes There? (Frozen Hell) in 1939 which you might recognize as the direct inspiration for John Carpenter's 1982 movie "The Thing"
Wayne Barlowe's Expedition has a complete alien ecosystem designed in ways genuinely biologically alien to typical human conceptions, and he also wrote God's Demon and The Heart of Hell, which aside from advancing the classical depiction of the Hell of Dante's Inferno into increasingly terrifying and revolting forms, also creates a Hell beneath Hell (the pit of Abaddon) that is so horrific and inscrutable even the demons who run Hell run in fear from it.
Michael Crichton's Congo, and Eaters of the Dead, while not bearing any trace of the supernatural, do bear similar themes to Lovecraft's earlier work outside the Cthulhu mythos, particularly involving racial degeneration and miscegenation.
Robert E. Howard's Conan the Barbarian, Solomon Kane, and Kull the Conqueror have Lovecraftian elements, but they are typically overcome with a minimum of distress and effort, rather than there being any question of the heroes' success.
C.S. Lewis' Space Trilogy is functionally Lovecraftian in its portrayal of alien races and their cultures as well as the entities that comprise Christian veneration, but of course from the completely opposite perspective that these supernatural entities generally constitute a very wholesome and generous treatment of humans - with the exception of the bad ones, who make Lovecraftian gods look quite nice and friendly by comparison, and the humans themselves, who are worse.

One cold winter's day, a number of hedgehogs huddled together quite closely in order through their mutual warmth to prevent themselves from being frozen. >>21501666
Are there really such a thing as images that are "inherently traumatizing"? I have seen this sort of sentiment thrown around going back to when I was a 12 year old kid in 2012. Nobody would plainly say it like how I'm saying it, but the basic sentiment was if you saw pictures/videos of things like gore, dead bodies, mass shootings, ect, it was generally expected that you would seek therapy over it or something.

Even among the people that posted the gore there was this sentiment that what they were posting was "traumatizing". I remember 8 years ago, when eight chan was still a thing, there was this board called /baph/. It was a board dedicated to trolling, doxing, messing with innocent people. Terrible, I know. And one thing I remembered them doing was that they would write their plans and what they wanted to do in gore images, so the "normalfags" won't be able to read them. Another example is that /b/ tumblr raid event that happened a long time ago, it was rumored that people killed themselves over it? I was a kid when it happened and I all I remember is being confused/amused by how serious people were about it. A long time ago I also read some posts about how facebook mods seek therapy over having to see gorey posts.

Where does this seeing dead bodies=trauma sentiment come from? To me, this whole sentiment seems to just be a thing that has been socially engineered in our culture rather than something that is biologically inherent. In the ancient roman days, everyday people were cheering for the deaths of Christians in the colosseum. Not too long ago, everyday people were going out on picnics to watch musket battles between the north and the south.

Is it really just their brain saying "society says that I need to be traumatized by this, so I'm going to be traumatized by it?"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm transferring from a community college to a state university. My applications are in and now I have to send partial transcripts. While it feels nice to be making tangible progress with my education, I have all kinds of other shitty emotions being dug up by this process. I was accepted into a university straight out of high school. Had everything gone right I would have graduated with my BA in 2021. But everything went wrong. My first year was horrible. I genuinely feel like I went throufh some kind of psychological torture. I dropped out after a year and decided to just go through a community college, but then the pandemic fucked me over. I was so exhausted by school (which I never liked, even back in high school I was miserable) and thought I'd learn a trade. The pandemic gave me the excuse to do that and so I did construction work for about 2 and a half years. That was a dead end, so I'm back in community college and getting ready to finish my AA this spring and restart university this fall.
Being back in school is really painful. I'm about to turn 24 and Im stuck in these 10classes with 18 year olds. All those feelings of anxiety and alienation I always had in school are back but now with the added dimension that I'm older and so far behind everyone else. Then the application process is reminding me of when I was 18 and going into university, and all I feel is regret and resentment about the choices I made and the decisions that were forced on me. These past 5 years feel like a waste. I didnt live a fun young life. I lived in a state of resentment and loneliness. I hate school and what it's done to me. I really feel like I was put through a meat grinder.

An excerpt from some short story i have been writing for fun on and off for the past 2 and a half months. Keep in mind the main character and narrator is beyond schizo:

I could feel the glares of my fellow students. Like a dry tongue licking me up and down my back, violating me. I could feel them all. Even the nuances of that invisible tongue were not lost on me. Their dumbfounded looks, the lack of understanding in them. They were filled partly with pity, partly with disgust, but mostly with a feeling of superiority. It was as if they couldn't fathom that a man could be independent of their lousy company. With every fibre of its being, my left hand had to wrestle the right one away from finally drawing the serrated edge bayonet knife, and going on a stabbing spree that would end only with my suicide. The blackness returned, stronger than before. My heart was pounding, my head was inflicted with a pulsing headache that stabbed at my right temple and an unbearable pressure within my chest was building. I managed to calm down after 5 minutes of muttering to myself in the school’s bathroom, and somehow the feeling subsided again. I had robbed the knife off of some crazy homeless bum when I was in the capital for a lavish banquet with my family, and started bringing it to school ever since I started seeing the shadows. The devil on my left shoulder was hushed away though and at least for the time being, my humanity steadfastly remained, as if bound by rusted chains to my body.
Exasperated, I trudged into the classroom having already decided that the day was going to be a heap of shit, that I was forced to sit in. Another one of these days huh?
Nearing the classroom, I could hear the jumbled echoes of dozens of conversations emanating from within it, making a single, large and incoherent wall of noise that immediately made me question whether it was too late to turn my tail and take the day off. My stomach curled into a knot.

As I walked into the classroom, I instantly found my seat, again by the window, three rows down. A seat close enough to the front, that I had to feign paying attention, yet far enough away to never be caught doing so. Looking at the others continuing their conversations, oblivious to my presence, I noted how comfortable they were around each other. Another strange knot formed in my stomach.
As I sat, waiting for the lesson to start, another student named Eleanor entered the classroom. Eleanor and I had known each other for years. Eleanor was the only other person whose face could stimy the numbness - even reverse it at times. Our eyes met. She smiled as she walked over to my table, but my expression remained the same, dead one as usual.
“Hi Ainsley.” she said.
“Hey… Eleanor” I replied, pretending that I had to remember her name for a second even though we had known each other for years.
“How was your usual trip to the capital then?” She asked inquisitively, still smiling.
I said I was going to the capital?
“Oh, you know. Same as usual, nice cars, nice food, terrible people” I said, making my tone of voice sound as unconcerned as possible while pretending to get something from my backpack. The last part of what I said was even true. The full truth was that I hadn't gone on my biweekly trip to the capital with my parents for about half a year at that point. Episodes were worse there.
“Right, that's what you always tell me.” She said with a playful grin on her face.
“Care to elaborate?” She asked, again with a sort of playful, yet stern tone, as if she were my mother and was trying to make me confess to stealing out of the cookie jar. I paused, stopped jumbling in my backpack and pondered what to say. While thinking I slumped back in my chair, carefully considering my words while I stared at the ceiling.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: It's harder to describe good times than bad times. When life's going well you don't care much about thinking too hard how you feel and why you feel that way. A satisfied mind doesn't need to question itself. It's pointless in trying to describe when something is going right, when things make sense, when the mind is clear and sharp. The bad times have much more thoughtfulness to them. Then you can't stop pondering why everything sucks and find endless reasons and create arguments and loops. When you are feeling bad you can't appreciate that you are creating all these thoughts, sometimes there's beauty in them. And the person in a good state of mind is unable to appreciate or even understand the thoughts of a depressed person, and when they understand they don't care much. The person in a bad state of mind is completely disconnected from the people that are happy and feel a sense of going in the right direction. There's but these two basic states people experience, the feeling of 'things are going in the right direction' and the feeling of 'things are going in the wrong direction ' and these two modes are irreconcilable. Sometimes I take a step back and my total insignificance and mediocrity hits me like a wave. I am not the main character. I am not even a background character that gets a 1 minute cameo. I am the extra seen for a millisecond that gets blasted by a random explosion & is never seen again (in an action flick).
I am like every other basic ass humanities grad who thinks he's special, but just ends up in the same meat-mill dead end jobs.
The only writer who has ever captured this dread effectively is David Foster Wallace's short story he did about an office worker.
I'm not even usually a fan of Wallace, but that story hit now hits me especially hard. I didn't really fully get it when I read it when I was younger.
Our education system heavily brainwashes and propagates the message that you are special--life is all about what you want to do, what you can achieve, and the sky is the limit. Young people have no one to sit them down and tell it to them straight. They have to figure out on their own how worthless they are since no authority figure has the balls to tell what people in the past knew intuitively: I am not worth shit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I guess I've gotten to a point where I'm basing the decision that will probably (according to the average modern man's experience) determine the shape of the next 20 years of my life on what the hypothetical hilarity of the situation, as in the most comedically out of left field and away from miserable choice possible. Train conductor sounds incredibly funny, to the point where I've been genuinely laughing about different imagined scenarios where that's my job for a solid hour now. Not only is it abstractly funny, by not being able to put into words why it tickles my senses, but it also has the benefit of getting you to different places around the country and some decent medical insurance deals. Obviously it has a fairly low employment rate here in the third world, but after 4 years of NEETing around I figured I might as well take the risks that I've been too cowardly to jump into for a long time. My accustomed sensibilities would lend me to the domains of the arts and media, since there's some 2 year degrees available for "sound engineering" (lel) and video editing and so on, but frankly that's both too predictable and it is more likely to kill my love for the medium than enhance it because the job opportunities have very poor conditions. There's also the typical automation/mechatronics/hvac maintenance and other practical options that, while relatively safe in terms of employment rate, seem incredibly dull to me, considering that I failed during my initial university run for an engineering degree out of pure sloth and zero interest in the field.
I don't know man, the idea of working on the train tracks during the day and making art on the side at night (or on the job, imagine that) sounds really neat. The only major issue would be that it's such a specific field, that if you were to quit you would find yourself in a deeper muck than what you've already left behind. Because this is all in theory, pure theory, and living theoretically doesn't work. I wouldn't be able to work in another country either.
I only have less than a month to make a decision, and I can't quite tell if I've just lost it or if I've found the light through relying on humor in my decisions. I'm just terrified of making a horrible choice and regretting it for the rest of my time on earth, so that might explain why I've resorted to laughing things off, out of despair. Or maybe I'm just pretending, despite truly getting belly laughs out of thinking about it.
I would attach a cool picture to this post in order to redeem its self-centeredness, but unfortunately the range ban reigns supreme.

>just new age gibberish at its core.
I don't think so. Miya was the only exercise in digital art truly native to the platform that has been executed thus far. Utilizing anonymity, malleability of persona to form your own extremist mini-cult, stylized around an isolatory, digital hikikomori lifestyle was novel, and still is. The philosophical inflection and accelerationism are somewhat sidelined by this. Miya has had a large, if unnoticed and uncredited effect on the online space -- similar to BAP: their influence is much softer and unconsciously memetic than direct continuities.

No-one has really filled the hole Miya has left. I have hopes for Remilia in terms of elevating digital interfacing for the interested few, but it is true that C. Fang has much less potency overall than Miya.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21503659
>"woahhhhh Nippon is like unknowable and untranslatable if you're a gaijin :("
Japanese isn't really tough to learn (especially with Heisig for the Kanji).

The whole problem with Japanese is that it requires insane amounts of context about the culture and language.
It is unironically faster and easter to just learn Japanese and read Japanese books instead of having a translation where every sentence is either written a completely new slang of English, or with a *) after every sentence to explain stuff like "sama" or words that are context and only there because of English grammar rules and other stuff.

Writing Japanese into English is like writing "hood slang" into proper English. No matter how hard you try, the end result will never satisfy, because "hood slang" is just simplified English which removes complicated to speak phones. Even if the translation is logically correct, in the "hood" it will always sound wrong.
The except same with Japanese. To make matters worse, Japanese has actually new rules and contexts. While "hood slang" is just simplified English with removed complexity and less meaning, Japanese hides and creates insane amounts of meaning, which is impossible to translate without sounding wrong in English.

For example tell me how you translate
"田中先生はいらっしゃる"
You know that you talk about
>the "sensei" (can mean teacher, politician, person who teaches you, etc.)
>that he "comes, or goes, or exists", depending on the context
>in a HIGHLY HONORIFIC way
>BUT, it ends informal, so this means you talk with another person close to you in hierarchy or lower than you

If you are fluent in Japanese this sentence sounds normal.

But if you translate it to
>My honorable teacher goes.
You are missing the context that you talk to a friend.
If you say
>My honorable teacher goes, friend.
You sound like you tested your dragon dildo yesterday.
If you say
>my teacher goes, friend.
You missed the very important honorific.

If you would translate it accurately, you would create additional sentences and context that was never mentioned in the original like
>Hey friend. You asked me about this amazing teacher yesterday. I love him so much that I consider him very honorable. He goes right now to another room, but he was just insane with what he taught me today.

As you can see, in English you have to completely go out of your way to include honorifics and "reduce the value" to make words like "honorable" be logically attachable to a person. Also you have to create a lot of context to make some things sounds logical, like talking casual with a friend while also praising someone who isn't there with you with honorifics.

English simply can't translate Japanese without either removing insane amounts of context, or you sound like an ultra creep and autist.

>>21503131
What I would call the "god like" languages
>whatever your "native language" is
>English
>Japanese

If you live in and English speaking country, then congratulations, you only need to learn Japanese for the full experience.

If you ask why:
For English:
>all Latin languages are already using the same writing as English
>English is commonly accepted as "world language"
>other Lating languages are simply worse. French is retarded to write and speak and overall just a downgrade. German, while the most spoken European language, is worse than English to learn and according to information per sentence, even less informative than English.

Japanese:
Japanese is a language you should only learn if you really want to go over the language horizon of Latin. While Japanese has the "MUH KAWAII" stigma of anime (like English has the stigma of murdering and enslaving terrorists), in reality Japanese if the best fit.
Japanese has all the advantages of Chinese in regards to writing, while still being very similar to Latin languages. In fact Japanese is more like Latin, if it would have done an 180 degree shift. Especially the combination of the Chinese writing system makes Japanese the language that has it all.

The biggest reason to actually learn Japanese for literature is because of how untranslatable Japanese is. Sure, if you want to talk about laws, Japanese and English are both the same. But if you want to talk about art, emotions, and mental world, then you need to learn Japanese to understand the literature completely.

The biggest problem of Japanese start from sentence structure, to context dependency, and honorific rules, that sound even for a medieval circlejerk of royal too complex.
One example: When the samurai were not fighting anymore in the time of Tokugawa peace, there was a honorific difference of over 100 different "ranks", combined with the normal shit show of the Japanese honorific system. Only to give you an example of how complex the Japanese language was in regards to hierarchy. If you combine this with the idea to "not say anything you can omit", and you have a language that is impossible to understand if you just translate it to English, where neither honorifics not context based omittance is either non existent, or straight up a grammatical mistake.

Irish speaker here, at this point in time there's no real reason to learn one specific dialect as the language is more or less homogenised via the education system teaching the standard variety. People from Donegal will have been exposed to plenty of Connachtisms and vic versa. Really the only reason to specifically try to learn a single dialect is LARPing and most speakers will find you quite daft for doing that as an outsider. Also there's very little difference in grammar between the dialects, the difference is more in accent/pronunciation and a handful of dialect specific vocabulary. Gaeilge Gan Stró is a very good series of intro textbooks and you should also get an irish-english dictionary and a grammar reference book.

It's pretty bad. I don't know if Duolingo is any good, because most ways of learning Irish are pretty bad. It's generally a second language for most people, to the point where official translations are often garbage.
You get a lot of people who go through Irish medium education and end up with a view like >>21498332 because access to natural speech is so restricted. It was deeply unfashionable to speak Irish for a long time and all centres of power kept English as their main medium, so it's not just English oppression but also the continuing class system which saw Irish as "country" and low class that killed it off. Flann O'Brien's Béal Bocht/Poor Mouth is about early nationalist hipsters going to an Irish speaking area to hear their beloved native tongue, only to find out they don't like any of the people or their way of thinking once they get there because they're all peasants. There's more depth to it than anon makes out, but a lot of phrases are related to a way of life that assumed nature and very different way of living than an Anglosphere lifestyle, so there would be no way to get a deep understanding of the language if you didn't have cows or talk about rocks a lot.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21498507
>about what he had (has?) done two weeks ago
had. If it happened in the past, it'll be some form of past tense, the only question is if it'll be normal past tense or some kind of perfect past tense using a conjugated form of "have" or "will" or something. Notice how you didn't wonder whether it is "did" or "done" since it's a completed action: your instincts are already good. I guess there are some weird edge cases in the subjunctive tense where you might say something like "I would have gone to the party but I have to prepare for tomorrow's meeting" where the tenses are a bit here and there, but it seems like you've got it, you're just second-guessing yourself. As far as learning to talk, just watch movies and tv in english and you'll assimilate it at that unconscious level. Studying is theory clear up misunderstandings, but real understanding comes from having a sense of what just sounds weird, and what sounds weird is a sense you pick up from listening to native speakers. English is weird about tenses and word order. The only way you'll get it to feel natural is listening to a lot of it. Luckily, there's more media in english than just about any other language.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21498804
English verbs inflect for tense, that is WHEN they took place, but (with very few exceptions) NOT ASPECT. Aspect is the action's completion. Compare.

>I loved her(, and still do)
>I loved her(, and do not lover her anymore)
vs
>A la amaba
>A la amabé

All "loved" indicates is that the action took place in the past. Periphrasis (other words) are needed to make this construction indicate aspect. I'm not going to copypasta the entirety of it, but tl;dr English has 12 total tense+aspect combinations based on four aspects (simple, continuous, perfect, perfect continuous) and three times (past, present, future). However, it's more accurate to say that English has 4 aspects (as stated) and 4 times, past, present, future, subjunctive, with the subjunctive being "could, might, may, should" and IN SOME USES "will".


Full usage
https://www.englishclub.com/grammar/verb-tenses.htm:

>>21498804
>>21498835
"Do/does, did, done" is one of the few English verbs that inflects for aspect; "He did it" implies completion. "He had done it" and "he did it" are grammatically different but semantically the same. "He had did" is incorrect because the past perfect is "had" plus the PAST PARTICIPLE, which is identical to the simple past in weak verbs ("walk, walked, walked" vs "sing, sang, sung").

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21498811
It's kind of just a warning that a lot of resources can have bad Irish or tap out at a certain level of Irish that doesn't reflect either its commonly spoken forms, or things that are useful outside high school literature exams under a kind of prussian education system.
The Irish language channels on radio and TV are better resources because they're designed for and by people who are native level speakers. But you'd probably have to surpass the level of someone who learned Irish to pass college entrance exams to understand some to most of those. It's like someone who is esl might be able to read or watch the news and understand what's being said mostly, having trouble with things understood by custom or some specialist terms, but they might have trouble understanding the guy at the bar trying to run football stats by him who is also being subtly racist. Most Irish people are at the basic FOB level where banking or reading the news or ordering something medium rare would be difficult for them, so you'll be functionally better than them with a few months of study, but to get better than them you have to drown out a lot of noise, kind of like you'd probably get better at English as a second language if didn't try to learn it off other immigrants solely who also spoke it poorly and with a bias towards your native tongue.
One of the important parts is don't necessarily trust that official standard Irish is good. It's often written by someone who is Irish second language because only people who learn it as a second language try to use the standard. Because of this there's lots of words where it's a technically perfectly legitimate to use the word, it will be in dictionaries as a viable alternative, and if you use it, every native speaker will know you're EFL.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>21499676

It's going to be boring. You should get a little bit familiar first.

I usually get a beginners book like assimil and just go through it a little bit every day. It's important to not get too caught up in trying to learn or understand everything in it. The most important thing is to be consistent and that you finish it.
I'd also do a little bit of something else to build vocabulary, if the language you're trying to learn is popular even Duolingo can be good for that.

Assuming that the language you're learning is not too dissimilar to the ones you know, this will probably leave you with enough knowledge to consume media and understand a good amount of it in 6 months or less. From this point on everything is easier and fun, usually the rest just falls into place naturally with exposure.

Though, if you're trying to learn a very different language -like an american trying to learn japanese- it's going to take significantly more work and time.

>>21503702
Talmud (both Yerushalmi and Bavli) consist of Mishna written in Mishnaic Hebrew which is older and can be read independently, and Gmara which is 98% Aramaic. Mishnaic Hebrew is similar to Biblical Hebrew, but has some differences, and a lot of unique words. Do you know Modern Hebrew by any chance? It helps a lot because Ben Yehuda based modern Hebrew on the language of both Mishna and Tanach. Especially constructions like אף על פי כן or לו are very popular in the Mishna. I've never learned Mishnaic Hebrew, I was learning Modern and Biblical Hebrew, then I opened the Mishna and I realized that I understand pretty much every word (still had some problems with understanding the text, because it is not literature, but more of an oral discussion written during the debate on paper with all the disadvantages of it).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>21505319
>Need help defining the summary of my story itself
>Like i have premise and characfers and the world itself and even the actions but i dont even know why are the characters are having conflict or i am afraid that the root of the conflict feels bad and unnatural
>So how do i begin to generate idea and then select the best one? I heard freewriting is like brainstorming but even so i dont know where is the storm like i cant even find enough data to choose so it fits my writing...

One way to approach this problem is to start by examining your characters and their goals. What do they want, and what is preventing them from achieving it? The conflict in your story should stem from the characters' desires and obstacles, and should be the driving force that propels the plot forward.

Another way is to think about the theme or message of your story. What are you trying to say or explore through your characters and their actions? Once you have a clear sense of the theme, you can then think about what kind of conflict would best serve to illustrate or explore that theme.

One technique you can use to generate ideas for the conflict is freewriting. Freewriting involves setting a timer for a specific amount of time (say, 15 minutes) and writing down whatever comes to mind without worrying about whether it's good or not. You can freewrite about the characters, their desires, obstacles and setting, it might generate some new ideas that you can use.

Another option is to brainstorm with someone, talking through different ideas and seeing what resonates with you. A fresh perspective can be very helpful in generating new ideas.

If all of this fails, one more technique can be looking at other stories, movies or books that have resonated with you and trying to find what specifically made them work. Analyze the story's structure, character, conflict and resolution and see if you can find inspiration from them.

Remember that the most important thing is to keep writing and experimenting, don't be afraid to try different ideas and see what works best for your story. And remember to have fun with it, creating a story is an exciting journey!

>>21505342
>>21505437
the second one isn't me, it's a troll
>maybe i could use a pointer on how to slowly, build things up
my advice is to start with introspection and critical thinking
why do you "do art"? what do you get out of it? what do you WANT to get out of it? is there anything you want to make other see or understand? are you drawn more to the aesthetic experience? what do you believe art is capable of at all - can it change people, is it a medium for meaningful experiences, is it entertainment?
if you start from the very fundamentals you are going to clear up what you want your art and your story to be and that will tell you what to write because if you arrive at the conclusion that you want it to primarily be an aesthetic experience the structure and plot (and prose) are going to be vastly different than if you want to talk about something specific (in which case you will tailor the story and characters and world serve that)

School is useless, grades are a horror that destroys people's interest in studying, and if your parents suck, your only hope is reading self help books.

The best advice for self help books is finding authors who have "skin in the game". This means if you are unsure, exclusively read books written by professors with one or more PhDs and a reputation to lose.

The best two self help books you should read are
>Make it Stick
>Influence
Those two books are the basis for everything.

In regards to Atomic Habits I would say that it's rather weak. Learning is a really complex topic and as long as you train your body every day, follow a schedule, and improving every day, you already do more or less everything helpful you can find in Atomic Habits.
For example Atomic Habits assumes that if you do everything 5 minutes a day, you can improve a lot. On the other hand books like "Deep Work" say that you need 2 hours of uninterrupted time to really go beyond super saiyan 2.

It's really tough, because so many books are useless like "Rich dad poor dad", which were written in a time when the main way of making money, houses, were cheap af. This is why so many "self help" books can suffer, because everything changes so fast, that a "secret" to be faster than the competition can be already outdated the moment the book is printed.

This is not true, in the time you've said it.

You're confusing facts. The brain does indeed finish physiological development around 25, but the growth after late teens is minimal. It does the last 0.1% from 19 to 25, thereabouts.

The personality being static during the lifespan is from around 17 or so. Personality traits vary very little after the end of puberty.

You have mixed up facts and combined them.

Also note that the personality as it relates to relationships (hobbies, how you make others feel, etc), and the personality dimensions as explained in academic literature and relating to developmental milestones are entirely different things. The latter does not measure the former in any meaningful way.

If we recognize that logic cannot create reality — only describe it — then it becomes obvious that an argument's truth value is completely independent of its correlation with reality. You could make the world's most rigorous argument for the idea that heat is actually cold and it will only change the fact that now it's cold that burns you. The actual, underlying mechanisms are independent of whatever you may layer on top of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I have ideas for stories that involve metaphysics. One I particularly like is a sort of Rip Van Winkle derivative set in modern times. Married man with two kids driving home on a freeway in LA. By chance a vanishingly rare phenomena occurs where his car is collides with a momentarily manifesting tear in space-time, completely halting the spin of every atom from the outer layer of the vehicle all the way inside. Including his own. He and the car are completely frozen in time, totally immovable and anchored to the earth below it and possessing a hardness that withstands any force that is applied to it. The incident gains world-wide renown almost instantly. "The Frozen Man" becomes the most famous person on earth. He's voted Time man of the year. Millions of people flock to the spot where his car is frozen to catch a glimpse of him. The man's wife and children are obviously devastated by this. The section of the highway is eventually cordoned off and covered by a large hangar, turning it into a giant lab for research, only accessible by authorized scientific delegations, US intelligence, military and the president...but the Frozen Man's immediate family are also allowed visitation. As years pass, many profound scientific discoveries are made as to the nature of matter. Frozen man's oldest son becomes the most frequent visitor among his family as wife can no longer bear the pain of seeing him. The son is a bit of a prodigy studies in school and eventually grows up to specialize in plasma physics. He becomes a regular researcher at the facility. He comes up with a novel method to observe the frozen matter and eventually dislodge and capture some particles from it using a particle accelerator. These captured particles were found to be capable of seeding a process to create exotic materials, capable of withstanding astoundingly high levels of heat. At year 20 after the freeze, the son is having a coffee break talking to his dad behind the glass and he notices that his dad's hand was slightly off of the steering wheel which wasn't the case. He also observed the beginnings of a squint in his eyes...as if he's about to flinch. Calling an emergency meeting, the scientists take measurements and discover that the frozen vehicle is in fact accelerating exponentially. They calculate that within 3 days, the car and everything in it will hit an inflection point and very rapidly come out of the freeze. They prepare by clearing a path for the vehicle through the hangar and out to a now abandoned section of the freeway.. With the whole world watching and anticipating on the third day, the car starts rolling forward slowly and then suddenly accelerates to 65 MPH and Frozen Man, who was a split second ago driving on a freeway was now driving inside a giant hangar. He pumps the breaks just as his car exits the end of the hangar in full view of news helicopters. His son, and others run out to the car as he steps out into a world that has left him 20 years behind.

>>21501864
Russia is a free market liberal paradise, so you only get what you get. A significant part of printing industry and book selling chain stores belong to a single corporate group — not even because of some government control, the Invisible Hand simply said so. They stick to same old profitable concepts, and optimize for that. The billionth reprint of Alexandre Dumas, self-help crap, countless battle sci-fi and battle fantasy series from no-names, etc. Most regular people have two options when it comes to classics: dirt cheap pocketbooks or not so cheap glossy hardcovers that are printed on the same toilet paper as pocketbooks. Sometimes freelancers hired to work on books forget to include end-notes or use some random copy full of OCR errors found on the net (even when the same book has already been printed by the same publisher). Putting illustrations of Ancient Greece into a text about Ancient Rome? Who cares! The suckers still pay for that.

See user photos for Dostoevsky books, for example:
https://www.labirint.ru/authors/11641/

There are smaller publishers who do better, but they target high-brow public, do business in sub-1000 or sub-5000 copies print runs, and have a giant backlog of planned titles. They have no interest in competing with cheap mass produced series.

There's one or two publishing houses that do produce the “high quality” editions of classic books, though, but their design decisions are driving me mad.
https://www.labirint.ru/series/38785/
https://www.labirint.ru/series/41989/

I mean, how do you even decide to waste a lot of decent paper to put it under this cover:
https://www.labirint.ru/books/635822/

No wonder that currently living artists tell them “NOPE, we're drawing the cover, too”:
https://www.labirint.ru/books/672150/

Then, of course, there are books for rich idiots. Leather, gilded edges, and idiotic full color frames on every page. Actual commentary, editing or design work? Probably not, they print the exiting digital texts the same robotic way it's done in pocketbooks.

But there is something money can't buy. Large scale academic publishing is all but dead. If you are a rich wanker who wants to put collected works of Aristotle or Plato on the shelf, your only choice are the same second-hand volumes from Soviet/post-Soviet editions everyone else can get from used books dealers. You can have them rebound and bleach the pages, but no one is going to make a new commented edition.

depends on what are you into

peter watt's blindsight has more ideas per 3 pages than most genres have combined
vernor vinge's a fire upon the deep is also very good sci fi adventure story full of immersive world building, very interesting ideas about ai getting involved in politics, interaction between species with extreme differences in development, standard sci fi stuff
neuromancer and snow crash are fun cyberpunk books that describe futuristic dystopias where most people live like shit and a bunch of hackers go on all sorts of adventures
turner diaries is a novel about a racist cult surviving against globohomo world order
ayn rant's atlas shrugged is a story about productive members of society hating collectivization and going on 700 page autistic rants about how collectivization is only good for parasites in society, you are obviously not going to like that one if you arent into those politics
i have no mouth and must scream is a short story with a very fun twist where a group of people suffers very tragically
i am legend is also a very fun short story with an awesome twist, its a zombie survivalism type thing but unlike all 3 movies you actually get why its called i am legend
hyperion is an extremely good series that goes to shit later in later books, world building is interesting but not as believable but the characters are extremely interesting and i simply had to keep reading to find out what happens

and so on
i mostly enjoy sci fi and short stories, audiobooks are especially good if you are going to hike long distances

In the year 1066 William the Misbegotten and his fellow Normans stormed into England, took wald from the Angle-Saxan, and set up a new, French-speaking lordship. Owing to this, French words bled into English over the yearhundreds, often taking the stead of inborn words with alike meanings. Today we can hardly speak English without leaning on French borrowings, and many folks are even unaware that English is in truth a Thedish tongue. Inborn words are reckoned to score between only 20 and 33 hundredths of our overall wordstock (though our everyday speech is still mostly Thedish).
The Anglish undertaking seeks to heal English, and rid it of its outlandish crutch. We do this in three ways: first, we choose to brook the inborn words we still have over alike outlandish words ("split" instead of "separate"); twoth, we breathe life back into dead words (Old English "wuldor" [splendour] becomes "wolder"); third, we twist words and make new meanings ("firsty" becomes "original")

>>21499970
Plotinus doctrines are scattered throughout the text. In each tractate he focuses on a specific issue but it's always written in a way that assumes you already have full background knowledge of Plotinus' overall philosophy. So the first few are going to be a hard slog until you can start piecing together what his actual views are. For this reason it's helpful to have a companion that explains Plotinus' philosophy so you get that background knowledge in order to understand each tractate better. Neoplatonism by R.T Wallis is considered one of the best.

Reading it is going to be like a puzzle where some of the early stuff will leave you baffled because it assumes you already know things elucidated in later tractates.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Notes from I.1:
>The individual soul has psychological distinctions.
It is clear that passions reside in a different part of the soul than ratiocination or opinion.
>Is the soul a composite aggregate?
Is there any difference between the soul and the soul-essence? If so then it is a composite aggregate. If not then the soul would be a form and we must admit it is immortal.
>The soul is not essence.
If the soul were essence she would not be able to partake in mixture or change; she would not have fears nor passions; she would be unreceptive and unperceptive of the external and unable to suffer. Yet all this is clearly not the case.
>The soul uses the body as a tool.
How do passions from the body penetrate into the soul? If soul were separate from the body then one individual would suffer while a different one would be affected. It is philosophy (logos) that separates the soul and the body, which were originally one.
>The relation of the body and the soul before separation was a primitive one.
They were probably mingled together, with the body being the independent part and the soul its instrument; however, philosophy raises the latter to the rank of the former, and she grows independent of the body.
>There are consequence of the mixture of the soul and the body.
The body improves by participation with the soul; the soul deteriorates by association with irrationality and death.
>The soul and the body cannot be completely mixed.
They are incommensurables.
>Not all affections are common to the soul and body.
There are some which require the excitation of blood and bile and are entirely bodily. The desire for goodness on the contrary belongs entirely to the soul.
>The soul's faculties, by presence, while remaining unmoved, cause reactions in our organs that enter them into movement.
The soul and body form an aggregate where the organism's life belongs to neither fully. If corporeal emotion finds its term in the soul, the soul feels.
>Animal nature is formed by the soul.
However it is not the soul's nature in itself; it is instead the nature of the composite formed by the soul and body.
>Our higher principles concur in forming the manifold complex of human nature.
Hence the soul-body feels sensation.
>The soul only perceives the typical forms, i.e. intelligible portion, of sense objects impressed on the animal sense.
The soul receives only image of the external sensation the animal feels. Rtiocination, opinion, and thought deal exclusively with these images.
>There is a superior part of the soul, we who direct this organistaion and a lower part of the soul which is mixed with the body and is irrational.
It is this part of the soul that partakes in Nous.
>The One hovers over intelligible nature. We, on the third hypostases, partake in the World Soul which permeates all bodies.
She is indivisible and in the universe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>If she does not mix with bodies then how does she give life?
She remains individuals and gives out images of herself. These images form the faculties of the individual soul: sensation in the common part; and the forms which derive successively from each other down to the faculties of generation.
>The World Soul in creation of the individual souls is foreign to the cause of the evils man suffers.
So is the highest part of the soul, even though ratiocination belongs to it, as the latter can be the cause of great evils when mastered by the lower parts of our nature.
>Often we yield to appetite and anger, and to even lower sensation. These are the result of the soul being duped by imperfect images.
Our imagination/fantasy does not await the judgement of discursive reason. In such a case the intellect did not grasp the object itself.
>The real Man differs from the body.
"We" is taken in a double sense: either the soul with the animal body; or simply the upper part, while the body is a beast.
>the virtues consist not in wisdom but in ethical habits and austerity. They belong to the common part.
Friendships however are some referred to the common part and some to the pure Soul or inner Man.
>The superior principle, which at first seems inactive in relation to us, only begins to be active towards us when it advances as far as the middle part of our being.
To utilise the superior principle, we must direct this middle part of our being towards either the upper or lowerd worlds. This is actualisation of Aristotelian "potentiality" or Stoic "habit."
>Animal bodies can be defined according to this animating principle as human souls that have sinned.
Those animals into whose bodies no human soul have entered are produced by illumination of the World Soul.
>The common doctrine that the soul sins and undergoes punishment in Hades is not necessarily incompatible with this doctrine.
Philosophy's separation of the soul refers not only to body, but to passible accretions. The combination of the pure soul with that which experiences passions and sins is what undergoes punishment.
>The animal nature is generated when the soul descends.
As she inclines towards the body the soul sheds light onto what is below her and thereby produces an image of herself. But when she is entirely occupied in contemplating the intelligible world, this image vanishes.
>It is we, by means of the soul which makes this research. The soul considers itself.
As for the Intelligence (Nous) it is only ours insofar as the soul is intelligent; for us the higher life consists in a better thinking, when the intellect is both a part of ourselves, and a part of something superior towards which we ascend.

>>21503932
>If this be so, then, indeed, we may think of the soul as an immortal—if the immortal, the imperishable, must be impassive, giving out something of itself taking nothing...
Giving out necessitates diminution; diminution necessitate destruction; destruction necessitates mortality. Is the soul self-destructive? No. The soul is not giving out but instead must be growing in. It is positive abundance.
>Whatever possesses Existence is supremely free, dwelling, unchangeable, within its own peculiar nature. And can any increase bring joy, where nothing not even anything good, can accrue? What such an Existence is, it is unchangeably.
Plotinus mistakes Existence for Existing. (As he did in the above excerpt when he mistakes 'soul' for 'soul-ing'). I've written this before, but I will write it once more: I believe—in regards to the Platonic Forms—that the Principle has been abandoned in favor of the Purpose. The Is Good, is abandoned in favor of the Being Good; Permanence enters Eternity—Permanence regresses into Eternity. Be turns into Being. This Being is not an Eternity, but is(-ing) an Eternity(-ing). The present-continuous as you know it. Eternity is accruing; thus, Existing is accruing. Hence, Happinessing and Joying are accruing so long as Sadnessing and Grieving are not destroying them.

Read people like Christopher Lasch (The Revolt of the Elites and The Betrayal of Democracy) Carl Schmitt (The Crisis of Parliamentary Democracy), Carroll Quigley (Anglo-American Establishment, Tragedy & Hope), James Burnham (Managerial Revolution). Democracy in the 18th century was predicated on liberalism, or the naive and crypto-aristocratic faith in the "natural" self-governing capacity of republics. Then in the 19th century this faith was challenged and by the early 20th century no one believed it anymore and even within the "liberal democracies" it was the norm to decry the death of authentic democracy and its replacement by "machine politics" and the manipulation of the mob. Authors like Roberto Michels and Oswald Spengler convinced basically the entire literate class that liberalism was no longer self-evident as a viable mechanism for democracy, and had to defend itself vigorously if people were to renew their faith in it. The fascist and communist states answered this crisis by simply repudiating liberalism and trying to find another basis for the democratic principle, either the volkisch organism or the communist utopia. These attempts either failed and lapsed into the same machine politics that the anti-liberal critiques had initially criticized.

Instead of actually answering the critique of naive liberalism, the "liberal democracies" went full steam ahead with propaganda efforts to renew and augment the naivete necessary to believe in liberalism after its age of crisis. People like Lippmann and Bernays were listened to and read by the entire emerging technocratic and financial elite, which was part of the aforementioned literate elite and read all the same critiques, and knew very well liberal democracy was in severe crisis and that ordinary people were beginning to flirt with alternatives. They chose the Lippmann/Bernays alternative, not because they rejected fascist and communist "totalitarianism" - they agreed totalitarianism was the inevitable end-point of post-liberal democracy, i.e. managerial technocracy. They simply rejected the "circulation of elites" that would inevitably result from a fascist or communist revolution: they preferred that the technocratic totalitarian machine maintain their class, the class that killed true liberalism by using it as a cloak to dominate society with financial power, at its head.

All we are seeing now is the end of this process, as the "Davocracy" (Huntington's term) developing from the post-liberal/managerial "new elite" has spent over a century in power compounding on itself, becoming ingrown and idiosyncratic, and effectively going senile. It is synonymous with Peter Dale Scott's "deep state," basically a writ-large version of the Tammany Hall style political machine, the "spoils system," except with total control over countries and ultimately international spheres of influence. Its outer party is drawn from the useful idiot apparatchiks who get Harvard degrees and use Twitter.

>>21503714
Also look into the brothers Henry and Brooks Adams: Degradation of the Democratic Dogma, and Law of Civilization and Decay. Look at what people were writing in the 1920s. They all took it for granted that democracy was in peril because no plausible substitute could be found for liberalism, which nobody actually believed in anymore. To be a "democratic liberal" in 1920 even if you had leftist or conventionally liberal sentiments was like being a libertarian today, it required either willful self-delusion or extreme naivete.

Everything you have taught about "democracy" and "liberalism" being relatively uniform traditions or relatively continuous political discourses for the last few hundred years is a lie: not only was there this massive crisis of faith in the ability of Enlightenment liberalism to absorb the shocks of industrial society and mass political participation, starting in the middle of the 19th century at latest and continuing all the way to WW2, even prior to this crisis there was great heterogeneity of discourse about both liberalism and democracy. Even in the Enlightenment heyday, most thinkers now associated with the march of progress toward states grounded in respect for negative liberty were extremely pessimistic, aristocratic, hateful and fearful of the mob. You can find incredibly prescient predictions of the impossibility of "mass" democracy, of the inevitability that financial powers will manipulate republics that are merely fortuitously composed of individuals without a strong overriding patriotic sense to unite them, etc., going back centuries.

Again, the narrative you have been told, of gradual progress toward greater and greater individual liberty through political "liberalization," is a propaganda narrative cooked up in the mid-20th century by the elites of the liberal democracies, all of whom knew very well that actual liberal ideals were a fantasy that could only have been maintained by sensible people into the 1840s at most. The narrative wants you to think that history was a series of partial and increasingly adequate realizations of the principle of negative liberty, and that now that this ideal has been realized, it is the human default. But it never even existed prior to its period of crisis: all the states most associated with "liberalism" were in fact dominated by highly politically active de facto oligarchies, with barely any input from the lower orders, most notably the most famous example of a successful parliamentary democracy, Britain. The American Founding Fathers were profoundly opposed to mass democracy and openly said that democracy was only possible in small republics - even the Thirteen Colonies with a few million people total already stretched the 18th century "democratic imagination." They would not recognize today's bloated "liberal democracies" at all, they would see them as oriental slave empires.

>>21505008
I haven't read the later version, but I have read the original and I have a rough understanding of what was done in the following version. The later version supposedly gets rid of the nationalist sentiment, the ideals of glory and courage in the face of danger, et cetera which make the original stand apart from other first-hand accounts of modern warfare—see the last ~20 pages of the original translation for the best example of this. Junger almost certainly edited these portions or got rid of them to keep the book in print, as the appetite for such writing was not exactly great after WW2, but in doing so, he reduces Storm of Steel to yet another run-of-the-mill memoir with the tired cliche of "war bad". I remember I just got out of a kinokuniya in NYC and sat across a park with my newly purchased collection of Mishima books. It was a good feeling as this was my first time in the big city and I felt quite ambitious and invigorated, doubly so as I began to remember the passion of Mishima works. As I sat there admiring the cover of the temple of golden pavilion, I saw a cute Asian girl from across another bench looking at me book in hand. I never had much luck with women because I lacked experience and confidence, after reading sun and steel I had gotten quite fit and fairly well groomed and dressed, so this was my first opportunity ever. The second time she turned we locked eyes and I shyly looked away. I decided it would be pathetic of me to not at least try so I struck a conversation and we talked about each other’s books. I began to describe in great detail about the life of Mishima and she was struck with great shock but luckily this manifested as an interest so she seemed to enjoy the conversation and so did I. We decided to walk around the city and she showed me her campus and some other cool scenic spots. She said it was getting late and I didn’t want to make it awkward so I volunteered to leave. We embraced each other, hugging and saying our goodbyes. Looking back had I been more confident I would’ve really sealed the deal probably stayed the night with her but I was too nervous. If you’re reading this Lynn, thank you for making me feel not disgusted with myself for once, thank you for bearing with my lengthy explanations. Mishima was my first step in getting a gf unironcially. Pic related is me

posts.com:
I have been reading these books recently. I like the way Erikson composes his sentences but I detest his approach to characters. Every character is either some immortal demigod or an elite, world-weary soldier/warlock/assassin who stops every five minutes to ponder the futility of life. Every other character is a woman or a negro, which means nothing in Eriksons world but still chafes because he never fails to describe them in case you were thinking about imagining them as white. I like that he doesn't try to do a Sanderson and produce some kind of autistic magic scheme that is really just marvel super powers but despite that the magic here feels way too powerful to be this commonplace. Characters appear that can level continents with their mind and yet somehow the world keeps spinning despite many of these characters being literally insane.

Also for a fantasy novel it never really takes a moment to revel in the fantastical. Every five seconds somebody is being burned alive or decapitated or being tossed into a dimension of eternal torment. It's like warhammer 40k but everyone is a redditor armed with a crossbow and knives.
